svcproc.title: ARMATURE SERVICING
svcproc.para: If the armature is worn, dirty, out of round, or has high insulation, the armature should be put in a lathe so the commutator can be turned down. The insulation should then be undercut 1/32 (.79375 mm) of an inch wide and 1/32 (.79375 mm) of an inch deep,and the slots cleaned out to remove any trace of dirt or copper dust. As a final step, the commutator should be sanded lightly with No.00 sandpaper.

note.para: The undercut operation must be omitted on cranking motors having Test Specifications 7104, 7113, 2412, 2415, 3501, 3564,3574 and 3599 as listed in SPECIFICATIONS. DO NOT undercut commutators on motors having these specifications.

svcproc.para: The armature should be checked for opens, short circuits and grounds as follows:

step1.para: Opens - Opens are usually caused by excessively long cranking periods. The most likely place for an open is at the commutator riser bars. Inspect for loose connections at the points where the conductors are joined to the commutator bars. Poor connections cause arcing and burning of the commutator bars. If the bars are not too badly burned, they can often be repaired by welding the leads in the riser bars (use rosin flux), and turning down the commutator in a lathe to remove the burned material. The insulation should then be undercut except as noted above.

Short Circuits - Short circuits in the armature are located with a growler. The armature is revolved with a steel strip (such as a hacksaw blade) held above it. The steel strip will vibrate above a short circuit location in the armature core. Shorts between the bars are sometimes caused by brush dust or copper between the bars. These shorts can be eliminated by cleaning out the slots.

Grounds - Grounds in the armature can be detected by the use of an ohmmeter. If resistance is shown one test point is placed on each commutator section and the other point on the core or shaft, the armature is grounded. Grounds occur as a result of insulation failure. This is often caused by overheating as the result of excessive over-cranking or by the accumulation of dust between the commutator bars and the steel commutator ring.
